title: 108_s2471
content: The Act may be cited as the "Safeguarding Americans From Exporting Identification Data Act" or the "SAFE-ID Act". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act, known as the "Safeguarding Americans From Exporting Identification Data Act" or the "SAFE-ID Act", defines key terms such as "business enterprise" and "health care business", which encompass organizations established for profit, health care entities, and those collecting personally identifiable medical information. The "SAFE-ID Act" defines personally identifiable information as including name, address, financial data, medical records, date of birth, phone number, email, social security number, mother's maiden name, and password. This information applies to various entities such as medical partnerships, emergency medical transportation companies, medical transcription companies, banks handling medical billing, and their subcontractors. The "SAFE-ID Act" defines personally identifiable information to include name, address, financial data, medical records, date of birth, phone number, email, social security number, mother's maiden name, password, state identification information, and driver's license number. SEC. 3. TRANSMISSION OF INFORMATION. Prohibition on disclosing personally identifiable information of US residents to foreign entities without compliance with privacy protections and safeguards. Opportunity for consumers to object before disclosure. The consumer has the right to object to the disclosure of their information to foreign entities and must be provided with an explanation on how to do so. Health care businesses cannot terminate a relationship with a consumer for objecting to disclosure. Business enterprises cannot discriminate against consumers who object to disclosure and must still provide financial products or health care services. Products and services offered by a business enterprise cannot be required to be provided through affiliated entities or jointly with nonaffiliated businesses. Incentives and discounts can still be offered to encourage a specific response to required notices. A business enterprise will be liable for damages if they knowingly transfer personally identifiable information to foreign entities resulting in misuse of the information. An injured party can take civil action in such cases. An injured party can sue in court to recover damages for a violation of the section. The Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission will create regulations to enforce the section and impose civil penalties for violations. SEC. 4. PRIVACY FOR CONSUMERS OF HEALTH SERVICES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will update regulations to require covered entities outsourcing protected health information outside the US to include in their privacy notice: notification of outsourcing to business associates, description of destination country's privacy laws, and any additional risks to privacy and security. The updated regulations will require covered entities to include in their privacy notice: measures taken to protect health information outsourced abroad, consumer notification and objection options, and certification of privacy and security measures for outsourced information. The updated regulations will require covered entities to include in their privacy notice the reasons for determining how the privacy and security of health information outsourced abroad is maintained. SEC. 5. PRIVACY FOR CONSUMERS OF FINANCIAL SERVICES. Section 503(b) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act is amended to include provisions regarding outsourcing nonpublic personal information outside the United States. This includes informing consumers about the outsourcing of their information and the privacy laws of the country it will be sent to. The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act is amended to include provisions on outsourcing nonpublic personal information outside the US. Financial institutions must inform consumers of risks to privacy and security when processing information in foreign countries and certify steps taken to protect outsourced information. The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act requires financial institutions to certify the privacy and security of nonpublic personal information outsourced outside the US. The Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act requires financial institutions to certify the privacy and security of nonpublic personal information outsourced outside the US. This Act will take effect 90 days after its enactment.
